When students receive funded research grants, these community members are motivated to study the topic in greater depth.

Thus, universities need to have a digital environment (or infrastructure) that can demonstrate all this dynamism of knowledge of all courses, department and centers inside of university. In the digital age, professors can follow the dynamism of knowledge from all departments, which would minimize horizontal barriers and still motivate arousing interest in new themes that emerge in the researcher's daily life. The key element of these initiatives is to bypass the horizontal and vertical barriers imposed on university processes. For this to happen, institutions need to use mapping tools to standardize all processes. Thus, strengthening the strategic planning of universities. The importance of horizontal and vertical networks in institutions (and between institutions) are essential to promote the development of products/services, exchange of knowledge and information, as initiatives to generate new and smart technologies, according to Giannetti et al. (2020). Therefore, procedures to reduce vertical and horizontal barriers need to be considered in any educational system, regardless of country. Therefore, procedures to reduce vertical and horizontal barriers need to be considered in any educational system, regardless of country.
5)
Dimension Social

Discussions on SDGs are becoming a global issue/demand. To achieve sustainable goals, companies and universities need to redesign and adapt their production processes to align their supply chain and customers. However, the market performs its activities at a very different speed from universities. The social barriers can be defined by the lack of alignment of the internal process of universities with the different organizational processes inherent to each institution.

In this case, social barriers occur with the lack of alignment from the content taught in the classroom with the real problems demanded by the economic market. Students often learn the content obtained only by books (textbook) without the dynamism and practical experience adopted by companies. With this bias, the introduction of these researches with active methodologies approaches has spread to a greater extent within some universities, as analyzed in Table 3. Active methodologies have helped the propagation of the SDG theme through case studies (Beynaghi et al., 2016). This can be translated with the result of Table 6. These 45 articles are described as case studies in different countries.

Depending on demand, some projects have broader skills than others within institutions. This often occurs due to the volume with which the projects are associated, the size and number of students in each institution.

Many universities are not aware about the importance of aligning their syllabus of all subjects of all courses to the themes of the SDGs. Universities have already awakened this interest, which has acted as leaders in the subject, as seen in Table 2, mainly because it has become a prerequisite for developing partnerships with external institutions and has helped to capture government and private resources.
6)
Dimension Communication

The university is an environment composed of students, professors, directors, service providers from different fields of knowledge, being an organization labeled for its multifaceted knowledge. With the diversity of knowledge and processes, the dimension of communication needs to be discussed in all spheres. Thus, many institutions contemplate integrated information systems contributing to circulate news quickly. In this case, the dissemination of internal communication needs to be managed and coordinated. This communication, in many cases, is not developed by professionals, which weakens the implementation and dissemination of SDG programs. This communication usually becomes an assigned task for a professor and/or researchers who are already overloaded with other demands. Thus, the SDGs campaign and/or program may or may not be a priority of the professor's activity, which makes this activity very dependent on the researcher's interest and not on the organization as an institutional goal.

For the conduction and dissemination of internal communication, universities should adopt internal procedures to implement indicators in order to signal the stages of development for everyone in the community. Körfgen et al. (2019) agreed that indicators are an important and useful tool to measure progress, but it must be ensured that the appropriate criteria are applied. Besides these indicators, the team could track the progress and evolution of the project implementation. Developing university management based on indicators is not always an easy task, mainly depending on the size and number of employees and students, making the system increasingly complex. According to the authors Sonetti et al. (2020), to map these initiatives from a holistic perspective, must be seen as a complex and multifaceted element embedded in a multi-layered network of relationships. However, this type of implementation demands a large team of professionals, engaged and with time availability to dedicate themselves fully to the project. To circumvent these problems, management tools emerge to try to introduce new internal procedures and reduce cultural resistance.

Given this sequence of barriers, the complexity of the process of disseminating and implementing the SDGs is at different levels of the organization, as analyzed in Figs. 10 and 11. From this systematization, this analysis serves for university managers to identify that each university is inserted in a different context that can affect the dissemination of SDGs. Depending on where the university is located, the national education system can be influenced by the barriers discussed earlier such as the norms, legislation and bureaucracies of each country. More deeply, these barriers were presented in the previous section, as they can be caused by internal factors to the university and external factors from market and society. The factors (internal and external) can be defined as variables that drive or delay initiatives to disseminate the SDGs.

These differences of factors are dynamic from country to country and have been necessary examined especifically. To meet this dynamism, we built a framework to discuss all the factors that can affect the implementation process with a detailed structure. Fig. 12 presents the relationship between internal and external factors that influence the organizational structures of universities.

The framework includes all factors (internal and external) that influence the SDGs in three pillars: (1) countries, (2) market and industry, and (3) universities. In the country pillar, factors are highly dependent by the national education system, as norms, resources and incentives are established in a top-down manner. With this public policies can be better established to encourage and promote companies and universities on the subject. As a result of governmental political policies, the government establishes special funding (internal calls) to promote research in the countries and without this support there is no research at the national level.

To analyze market and industry, geographic location can be a determining factor depending on the economic environment where the university is inserted to promote dissemination, as in economically poorer states it may not provide necessary resources, which weakens collaboration networks and the characteristics of companies in the region. This limitation impacts the development of technology transfers from universities to the market. With companies with low economic development, the search for new and intelligent solutions is not required and stimulated (Giannetti et al., 2020).

Considering the factors that impact universities, it is noteworthy that, initially, there are elements that refer to the size of the institution and its availability of resources. This implies that some institutions have greater projection and, therefore, may have a more favorable environment for the implementation of the SDGs.

In universities, projects are supported by resources from financial sources (internal or external). To promote research in the academic community, universities periodically open internal funding calls to encourage teaching, research and extension. After the submission of the project by the researchers, the process goes on for evaluation, which requires an external evaluator so that they can validate the merit of each submitted project, according to the criteria, objectives and areas of knowledge previously mentioned in the public funding call. When these projects are approved, each project has its execution time according to the presented schedule that meets the universities' future strategies.

From this execution, the project obtains results to meet the demanded needs as a return on investment for society, but not always a satisfactory result is obtained. Because applied research depends on several factors to develop a new technology (or innovation), mainly the time, the maturity stage of the project and the alignment of the researchers' experience in the execution. Thus, scarce resources need to be allocated to projects that aim to contribute to the transformation of society (Leal Filho et al., 2019; Zamora-Polo and Sánchez-Martín, 2019). New models of sustainable education emerge with the aim of changing the mindset of future generations starting at an early age, then promoted through education at undergraduate, graduate and in the market environment. The alignment between all links in the country, university and market and industry chain (see Fig. 12) has a direct impact on the pillar of quality of life for all those involved in the environment, since the result of research advances, education models and factors (internal and external) of the university.

Other pertinent factors deal with the organizational culture for performing better communication between the members of the institution, facilitating and providing a harmonious and collaborative work environment. The union of these internal factors need to be expressed and disseminated through communication and institutional marketing, because today no university can survive without this tool as it is a requirement of the global market. The speed of this demand has emerged more and more in this period of the pandemic where universities need to adapt to new technologies and align research with market needs.

The studies analyzed in this systematic review elucidated the importance of the HEIs implementing the 2030 Agenda, addressing experiences of incorporating the SDGs in the context of these educational institutions. This theme has gained more attention in the research agendas, as guides are published and disseminated that stimulate and engage debates on how universities are arenas for the formation of knowledge and practical application of guidelines for sustainable development. Around the world, actions aligned with the 2030 Agenda are multiplying, and universities are more attentive to the incorporation of the SDGs in university environments since experiences were observed from several universities that address the SDGs both in their management, as well as in teaching, research, and outreach.

Furthermore, the systematic review identified that in some HEIs specific SDG implementation. Meanwhile, other HEIs operate the SDGs implementation as a network movement that seeks to promote the SDGs not only for a single university, but dialoguing between them, with several exchanges of experience within these institutions. This brings more maturity about how to implement and manage the SDGs in academic institutions. In the majority of analyzed studies, the results from these articles reflect only specific experiences not reflecting a broader view of SDGs implementation and management.

Was observed that the studies used quantitative and qualitative approaches and mainly employed documentary analyses and questionnaires, developing analyses that reflect how students and the academic community, in general, articulate the theme (SDGs). In addition, a significant number of studies addressing the incorporation of SDGs in the dimension of university management and integration with teaching have also been identified, with a smaller number of studies that are interested in aligning SDGs with research and outreach projects.

The literature points out that there is no consensus on where to begin implementing the SDGs in HEI. Although, the final balance sheet shows that there is a large repository of practices to be investigated, translating a critical role played by Higher Education Institutions that assumed the prerogative to be implementing and disseminating agents of the SDGs, as recommended by the sustainable development solutions network (SDSN).

Was observed that a set of initiatives can be adopted by HEI to: 1) systematize the implementation of SDGs, 2) start actions aligned with institutional documents and strategic mission; 3) integrate the SDGs with curriculum and learning; and 4) disseminate the awareness through training in university community.

Otherwise, the research path also identified a set of necessary good practices to effective incorporation of the SDGs in HEIs: 1) Develops a guideline on SDGs awareness and how to be more sustainable in academia; 2) Change the organizational culture, observing how specific actions can be aligned with each 17 SDGs; 3) Support of presidents and directors from HEIs to implement institutional SDGs actions; and 4) Creates a tool to identify and guide the adderence of all actions, projects and documents to SDGs.

All these aspects suggest the possibility of future research considering a more deep exploration in this theme, especially in two main aspects: 1) Case studies on best practices and evaluations of specific interventions in institutions that have exceeded in the incorporation of the SDGs; 2) Analytical indicators can also establish comparative parameters for examining HEI experiments in the SDGs. It is worth questioning how this process of incorporation occurred, understanding the emergence of the initiative and the current level of maturity of these HEIs about their alignment with the guidelines of the 2030 Agenda.

The post-COVID pandemic moment demands rethink how the SDGs can be important guidelines to accelerate and restore levels of efforts to bring gains to society in a moment of health recovery on a micro and macro level. Thus, HEis should demonstrate commitment not only to the impacts of COVID in society, but also collaborate to identify strategies and guidelines to boost public policies of regeneration of health conditions identified previously. During the period of the pandemic, institutions needed to adapt to online classes, which made it more difficult to disseminate the actions of the SDGs in the institutions, as this implementation process became remote.

Regarding the limitations of this systematic review, it is necessary to emphasize that the approach was generalist and not focused on any SDGs, which may have eliminated some experience developed by an HEI on one of the specific SDGs. Another point is that the interpretation of the research was hampered by the fact that many of the studies did not make explicit some information about the context of the experience, making it difficult to fill the analytical framework elaborated by the researchers. Other future research would: 1) Identify specific SDGs more frequently mentioned by HEIs; 2) Develop a framework to HEIs with all steps to SDGs implementation; 3) Develop performance indicators to evaluate the success on implementation; 4) Develop a information system to HEIs on SDGs benchmarking; and 5) SDG stamp on certification on HEIs alignment with SDGs.

The present study collaborated with a vision about implementation of the SDGs in HEIs. This research can be a useful instrument for professionals and managers of these educational institutions on SDGs knowledge that have been implemented in these organizations, observing main initiatives and barriers influencing the SDGs management performance.

Finally, it is emphasized that the general contribution of the article can stimulate the support of other HEIs in the implementation of the SDGs, besides being a relevant source of consultation for researchers who seek to understand the state of the art of the theme of Sustainable Development Goals in Higher Education Institutions.
